result.execSummary:
The defendant Montgomery Robert Tappy was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Montgomery Robert Tappy is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Montgomery Robert Tappy was found guilty of Possess w/ Intent-Amphetamine(>10-50g) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(e)3.
  • Montgomery Robert Tappy was found guilty of Maintain Drug Trafficking Place [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.42(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Remit fines and costs. Payment of DNA Surcharge only on both counts- payable from available prison monies.

No possession or consumption of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid Rx. No contact with co-deft's. No contact with known drug users or sellers, unless in a treatment setting and only with prior agent approval. May not vote or serve on a jury until civil rights are restored.
Maintain/obtain full time employment. Any other assessments, counseling and follow through as recommended by agent. DNA Sample Due: 6-20-22.
